The Future of PMM

Issue #1 ‚Äî Friday, February 14, 2026

üìù Friday Note

This week I had the chance to sit down with David Yockelson, a Research VP and Gartner Fellow who leads their product marketing practice. The conversation gave me the clearest framework I've seen for thinking about where and how to deploy AI across PMM activities.

The big insight? Not all AI investments are equal ‚Äî and the framework he walked me through (Defend / Extend / Upend) maps different activities to different competitive ambitions, return profiles, and investment levels.

We're also running two surveys right now ‚Äî Gartner's and our own AI Tools assessment. Take both if you haven't already. We'll use the results to build a prioritized transformation roadmap.

Enjoy!

‚ÄîChris

üìã Action Required

Gartner Product Marketing Skills Assessment

As Dan mentioned, we've partnered with Gartner to conduct a brief, anonymous skills assessment that benchmarks our function against other technology organizations.

The assessment covers 18 product marketing activities across five core areas:

  • Understanding the market
  • Knowing your audience
  • Communicating value
  • Enabling go-to-market teams
  • Managing product marketing teams

This is not a performance review or individual evaluation, so please be open with your responses as it will help us calibrate and identify the PMM capabilities training we need to provide to you.

To reiterate:

  • ‚úÖ Individual responses are anonymous; we will not see who selected which answers.
  • ‚úÖ Gartner will only know if someone participated, not your individual responses.
  • ‚úÖ Your input directly informs our priorities for capability development, tooling, and enablement.

You should have received an email from Gartner yesterday inviting you to complete the Product Marketing Score assessment. Please take the time to complete it if you haven't already.

‚ö° Featured

What Gartner Gets Right About AI in Product Marketing ‚Äî And the One Thing They're Missing

I sat down with David Yockelson ‚Äî a Research VP and Gartner Fellow who leads Gartner's product marketing practice ‚Äî to figure out how we should think about deploying AI agents across our teams.

The Framework: Defend / Extend / Upend

Gartner maps PMM activities into three buckets based on competitive ambition:

üõ°Ô∏è Defend (Parity)

Augmenting individual productivity. Content generation lives here. Investment: ~$500/worker/year. Return: "Return on Employee"

üìà Extend (Differentiation)

Transforming processes for competitive advantage. Example: AI-powered continuous competitive intel. Investment: $250K - $5M. Return: Actual financial ROI

üöÄ Upend (Disruption)

Creating new products, markets, value props. Cross-functional GTM workflows, agentic AI. Investment: $20M - $250M+. Return: "Return on Future"

Key Insight: Each PMM activity has its own trajectory. Content = AI-led now. Persona development = build, don't buy. ICP refinement = human-led migrating to hybrid.

The real prize? Not the activities themselves ‚Äî it's what happens between them. Connected workflows. Shared data. Eliminated handoffs.

Read the Full Analysis ‚Üí

We're collecting data on what AI tools you're currently using, what's working and what's not, and where the gaps are.

Combined with Gartner's survey results, we'll map everything against Defend/Extend/Upend to create a prioritized transformation plan.

üõ†Ô∏è Tool of the Week

Copy.ai ‚Äî GTM AI Platform

Since content creation is now firmly in "AI-led" territory per Gartner's framework, let's look at a tool leading that shift.

Copy.ai goes beyond basic content generation ‚Äî it's positioning itself as a full GTM AI platform with workflows that span content, competitive intel, and sales enablement.

Why it fits the framework:

  • Content generation: Fully AI-led (Defend tier)
  • Sales emails: AI-led with human approval
  • Workflows connect multiple activities (hints at Extend)

Real use case: Automated battlecard updates that feed sales playbooks without manual intervention.

$6.5B ‚Üí $58B in 8 years (37% CAGR)

The AI marketing industry has grown 9x in 8 years ‚Äî that's a 37.2% compound annual growth rate, more than 2.5x faster than the broader martech industry.

What's driving it?

  • 88% of marketers now use AI daily (up from ~30% in 2021)
  • AI-driven targeting delivers 26% better ad performance
  • AI-generated creatives increase CTR by 47%

Source: AllAboutAI / SEO.com

üì∞ News Roundup

1. Matt Shumer's Viral Essay: "Something Big Is Happening"

The HyperWrite CEO's 5,000-word essay comparing AI's current moment to February 2020 is everywhere this week. His thesis: we're in the "this seems overblown" phase of something much bigger than COVID. The piece resonates because Shumer isn't making predictions ‚Äî he's describing what already happened to AI workers and warning everyone else they're next. Read it ‚Üí

2. SAP Joule Studio Goes GA with Agent Builder

SAP's Joule Studio agent builder is now generally available, letting teams build custom AI agents on BTP with support for frameworks like CrewAI and LangGraph. This is the infrastructure layer for Upend-tier transformations. Read more ‚Üí

3. Anthropic's Claude Gets Persistent Memory

Claude Pro and Max users can now enable memory that persists across conversations ‚Äî no more re-explaining your projects, preferences, or context. For PMMs using Claude for ongoing work, this is a significant workflow upgrade. Learn more ‚Üí

4. LinkedIn Accelerate: AI-Powered Campaign Manager

LinkedIn's AI features now automatically adjust bidding, placement, and creative delivery to maximize campaign objectives. Another example of Extend-tier automation arriving in B2B marketing. Explore ‚Üí

5. Salesforce Agentforce Comes to Marketing Cloud

Agentforce actions are now available in Marketing Cloud Account Engagement, helping manage prospects and nurture campaigns from anywhere in Salesforce. Cross-functional GTM orchestration is here. Read more ‚Üí

üìä Survey Results Preview

Early results from our AI Tools assessment (100+ responses):

Most used tools:

ChatGPT/Claude 89% Grammarly 67% Jasper 34% Copy.ai 28%

Biggest gaps:

  • Competitive intelligence (58% want better tools)
  • Win/loss analysis (52% manual only)
  • Sales enablement content (47% seeking automation)
